CUSTOM_FIELD: You can use this for your after-effect code! Maybe turn it into a list of special opcodes in your ISA?
AFTEREFFECT:
for x in range(0, len(code)):
    code[x] = code[x] + f'          // This is an after effect on line {x}!'
----BASIC----: These are basic instructions, you should aim to fill in all of these as they will be used frequently in programs. The compiler may crash if certain instructions are missing.
----NOTE----: This is an example of a three-operand instruction, you need to replace it with your ISA's equivalent. <A> is where the result of the instruction will be stored, <B> and <C> are the inputs.
-----NOTE----: This is an example of a two-operand instruction, <A> is the destination and <B> is the input. Remember - a new string in the list is a new line in your ISA code.
---NOTE----: This is an example of a one-operand instruction, <A> is the only input.
----NOTE-----: This is an example of a zero-operand instruction. You do not need <A>, <B>, or <C>.
----COMPLEX----: These are complex instructions. You may wish to leave them blank if your CPU does not support them. In a future version, you may choose to use pre-written subroutines for these using only the core instructions.
